status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
As a user of the Eucalyptus Management Console I would like the ability to view and edit a CORS policy for an S3 bucket so that I can allow items in that bucket to be accessible from applications on distinct origins/domains.  I would also like sample policies to be available so that I can quickly and easily apply a common CORS policy (e.g. a read-only policy) to my bucket.

NOTE: This story includes offering example policies -- we will need to determine what sample policies to surface in the console.

Here's a sample policy for exposing S3 objects as read-only to any origin:
{code}
<CORSConfiguration>
 <CORSRule>
   <AllowedOrigin>*</AllowedOrigin>
   <AllowedMethod>GET</AllowedMethod>
 </CORSRule>
</CORSConfiguration>
{code}

Other sample CORS configurations are available at https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/cors.html#how-do-i-enable-cors
fields.summary: Enable viewing/editing CORS configuration for a bucket

comments.body:
Hi [~kgill],
Just letting you know that the parts of CORS you need in Eucalyptus are already there in v4.3.0. This includes the ability to create, store, view, edit, and delete CORS configurations, which are stored in our Eucalyptus database. The parts of CORS that are unfinished are the processing of in-flight and cross-origin HTML requests, which you do not need, IIUC.

The sample looks good. It has the basic XML structure they can expand upon. I'm not sure we need to provide any more complex samples, since users really need to understand how to populate a CORS config for their needs, by following the AWS docs you reference.

Thank you [~lincoln.thomas].  It's good to hear the CORS bits are already there in 4.3.0, and my initial testing of the GUI-2736 branch against Eucalyptus looks good so far.  I should be able to wrap up this ticket in the next few days.

BTW, how is Eucalyptus handling the CORS XML schema validation?  When I tested saving an invalid CORS XML string on AWS, I got a "The XML you provided violates our published schema" (-- I probably don't have the exact wording here since I'm writing this from memory).  Unfortunately online searches for the "published" CORS XML schema have turned up empty, so I created a fairly simple RelaxNG schema the console uses to validate the CORS config -- see https://gist.github.com/kamalgill/14dc00c43c3a75cde2f1222394b48c85

My CORS code will return the same string as AWS if you try to put a bad CORS XML config: "The XML you provided was not well-formed or did not validate against our published schema." But just to be a compatible message, since we haven't published a schema either.

The closest thing I can find to a schema is the table in http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/RESTBucketPUTcors.html, which is not in any sort of schema form.

I like your schema, maybe that's the one we should publish for Eucalyptus. You can also add the optional "ID" element, which is an arbitrary string up to 255 chars that identifies a rule.

Your wireframe https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Bucket+details talks about validating the CORS config, e.g. missing an AllowedOrigin. My CORS code validates some things, but is not comprehensive. It validates well-formed XML, unique rule IDs and <256 chars, and not >100 rules. Perhaps we should expand this validation in the base CORS code (not in the console) to be more complete, which the console would also call? Including:
(from that http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/RESTBucketPUTcors.html)
* Each CORSRule must identify at least one origin and one method.
* AllowedOrigin and AllowedHeader have at most one '*' wildcard each.
* MaxAgeSeconds is non-negative.
That's all I know that's missing, which I could add. Then it comes down to how the console should call it, and what errors you should get back in what form so you can use it.

Thanks for the feedback [~lincoln.thomas]! I've updated the schema to add the optional ID element, and I modified the MaxAgeSeconds datatype from integer to nonNegativeInteger.  There doesn't seem to be a way to restrict the AllowedOrigin/AllowedHeader wildcard rules to one per CORSRule element in a RelaxNG schema, so we'll probably rely on Eucalyptus to validate that.

Hi Jenny,

This one's ready for UX review.  Note that you'll need to run (in Terminal) 'brew install libxml2 libxslt', followed by 'sudo python setup.py develop' on the GUI-2736 branch to properly review this.

PR is at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/2060

hi [~dkavanagh] and [~kgill], Since I did not do the UX design on this one, I think we need a different person to be accountable for the UX review so we can get this one moved through. 

I'll bring this up at our team meeting, but if the implementer is the same person that did the wireframing, then please assign this to someone else on the team to UX review. Any reviewer can check the behavior and the visual stuff like text and capitalization, and tickets will get moved through the review process faster that way than waiting for me to be available.

[~kgill]
- small typo in bucket details "... contain the {color:red}ste{color} of origins/domains ..."
- Should the "Sample CORS Configurations" link be called "CORS Configuration documentation"? That's really what it is, not a list of sample policies. Also, our console has typically defined our own help text and here we're linking to AWS ([~jloza] what do you think?). Not that they don't have good docs, but it's a change for us.
- I notice the button text on the add/edit/delete dialogs is not all caps as elsewhere in the app. The button is also a solid green and not the green box w/ white background and black text we use elsewhere. I think the font is also not the same (or at least, not as heavy).
- I want to note the difference in how this button behaves relative to others in the app. I like this way, honestly, but the other buttons get replaced by text w/ a busy indicator after they are clicked.

Other than that, I like it!
yeah, we shouldn't be linking to their docs. Need to fix that...

Fixed typo and button styles in CORS dialog.

Regarding the "Sample CORS Configuration" link, it's in the (approved) wireframe and it's consistent with the AWS console, although I'm open to removing it if we link to our own docs.  Should we leave the link there until we have inline help or docs available?

/cc [~tvo]

Submitting for another UX review after typo and CORS dialog button style fixes.  [~dkavanagh]: could you pass this along to [~jloza] after your review to address how to handle the sample CORS config link?

[~kgill] want to just talk w/ Jenny about that? She said not to link to their docs, so I assume DOC ticket should be filed and we can link empty help file for now? That's what you guys should discuss, then kick back to me for review/merge.
Yeah, we should document that ourselves. Work with [~tvo] to figure out how to do that, plz.
Removed "Sample CORS Configurations" link in CORS dialog from the wireframe and implementation.
AWS will not publish the CORS configuration document schema.  I have asked them to update the error message to be less misleading.
Moving 4.4.0 Issues from Release Pending to Resolved
